In the niost clean-cut and interesting exhibition of baseball that has
been seen at Homewood this year,
Hopkins defeated Washington College Saturday by the score of 2 to I.
The game was a true pitchers' duel,
each team getting only four hits; and
the 'Varsity was able to win only by
taking advantage of Bourland's
error in the eighth and by holding
the enemy to their lone tally by
some of the cleverest fielding seen
this year. at Homewood.
The team has shown a remarkable
improvement in fielding. Worthington had four outs and five assists
to his credit without an error. He
handled himself in excellent form
and scooped up everything that
came his way in faultless manner.
On two occasions he ran out into
center field and made sensational
catches of high flies. Phythyon,
playing in the outfield in "Babe"
Ewing's absence, made a beautiful
catch of Bourland's long fly in the
seventh.
One of the most pleasing features
of the game was the fielding of
Howell at first. When it was first
announced that Butler would not be
able to play, a serious problem confronted the coach, but Howell's playing on Saturday showed Hopkins
that they have a man who is able to
meet the emergency. Howell accepted fifteen chances without an indication of a fumble. Howell also
figured in two double plays, both of
which were largely instrumental in
keeping the score of Washington
College to one tally. •
More encouraging, however, than
the playing of individuals was the
machine-like precision that accompanied the playing of the whole
team. Coach Hooper :has trained
his men well. The score:
.7Qhns Hopkins.

The last four of the Turnbull
lectures were delivered by Sir Walter Raleigh, of Oxford University,
on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday
and Thursday afternoons of last
week. The lectures, which dealt
with "The Reviewers,- ."Hazlitt,"
"Lamb" and "Landor,- respectively,
were easily the most interesting of
the course, partly because the subjects made it possible for Sir Walter to express his own views and
impressions, and partly because he
seemed to take an even keener delight in delivering them than in discussing the topics chosen for the
first two talks.
The lecture on "The Reviewers"
was by far the most original and
witty of the six discussions. After
dealing briefly with the futility of a
large body of criticism, Sir Walter
selected .the critics of the early nineteenth century, and devoted his consideration exclusively to them and
to their work. His discourse
abounded in clever epigrams and
ant phrases that embellished the
scholarly manner in which the subject was treated.
The following lecture, which dealt
with Hazlitt, proved of almost equal
interest. The life, the personality
and the work of the delightful essayist were carefully considered, and
the memory of a man who has been
all too effectually forgotten and become but a name even to many comparatively well read and thoroughly
educated people, was made fresh in
the minds of the audience. Details
of the personal habits of Hazlitt
were received with particular interest, for his character was in many
ways a most amazing one.
On Wednesday the speaker dealt
with Charles Lamb, shyest and most
retiring of men, after first apologizing for dragging so thorough a
recluse from his beloved retirement
into the light of common day. The
life of the writer was first discussed,
following which his work, which
was written late, and has aptly been
called a happy accident, received attention. The lecture was divided
into three sub-heads, which concerned themselves with the sayings,
essays and letters of Lamb. Some
of the wittiest remarks of the famous punster were quoted, and several of his letters, among them one
to Mrs. Wordsworth, were read.
The last lecture took for its subject Walter Savage Landor, a writer
who, said Sir Walter, is liked by
many, but enthusiastically loved and
extensively read by but very few.

The representatives of the Grotius Society of Johns Hopkins University were awarded the unanimous
decision of the board of judges
in a debate held with the team
of the Zelosophic Society of the
University of Pennsylvania at 8.30
last Friday night in the University
chapel. The debate was the fourth
that has been held between the two
societies, and the first that has been
won by a Grotius team.
Dr. John C. French, who was the
presiding officer of the evening, first
apologized for the small number
who had been able to be present,
adding that the debaters, like John
Milton, were assured of "fit audideuce, though few." He then introduced Mr. Edmund M. Spieker,
who rendered a piano selection with
characteristic ability and power.
The Grotius speakers defended
the affirmative of the subject: "Resolved, that a policy of colonial expansion is desirable for the modern
State." Their team was composed
of Cecil H. Bagley, '17; Reuben
Oppenheimer, 'i8; and Avra M.
Warren, '15 (chairman), while the
Pennsylvania debaters were D. T.
Balmer, '16; A. L. Horst, '16; and
H. H. Burton (captain).
Mr. Bagley opened the debate for
the affirmative with a well-ordered
and convincing speech that cleared
the field for his team-mates. Mr.
Oppenheimer, the second Grotius
speaker, was emphatic and his
speech was most capable, while
Avra M. Warren summed up the
position of the affirmative in a witty, extemporaneous address, which
was effective and to the point. All
three.speakers did! well in rebuttal,
but to Mr. Warren must be given
chief laurels, as he seemed to possess the most thorough acquaintance with his subject and was most
successful in riddling the contentions of the opposition.
Balmer, who opened the question
for the negative, dealt with the history of colonial expansion. His
speech was good from the standpoint of argument, but lost somewhat in the delivery. Horst was
the most easy and fluent talker on
the Zelosophic team, both in his
first address and his rebuttal. Burton, who spoke last, emphasized the
lack of land! open to colonization.
After a short interval, Prof. Wilbur F. Smith, chairman of the
judges, announced the decision of
his colleagues, Rev. Robert P. Kerr,
D. D., and Summerfield Baldwin.
The decision, which had been
reached without consultation, was
unanimously in favor of the Hopkins men.

Work has been started on the
new Yale boathouse at Gales Ferry.
The building will be 42 feet wide
and 85 feet in length and will be
supported on piles; a platform will
be constructed at one end with large
aprons and a 6o-foot float extending out over the water. The boatroom takes up most of the first floor.
On the same floor will be the dressing and shower rooms for the use
of the crew. Servants will have
separate accommodations on the second floor. A stairway in the entrance hall leads to the second story,
where there will be sixteen separate
bedrooms and a sitting-room open-

ing on a balcony which overlooks
the water. The new boathouse will
be a great improvement upon the
old one, which has stood for twentyfive years and has long been inadequate.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 19, 1915.
HOPKINS DEFEATS MIDSHIPMEN

TAPPAN STARS IN NAVY MEET

Black and Blue Lacrosse Team Scores
First Victory Over Navy in Three
Years—Middies Outplayed.

"Old Reliable" Makes Nineteen Points of
'Varsity's Total of Thirty Navy
Rolls Up Fifty-Eight Points.

For the first time in three years
the 'Varsity twelve triumphed over
Navy in the annual lacrosse battle
at Annapolis, the score being 4 to 2.
A large number of rooters accompanied the team and added to the
enthusiasm throughout the contest.
It was a clear-cut and decisive
victory, Hopkins outplaying the
Annapolis team from start to finish.
However, the game.was desperately
fought, the sailor lads trying their
best to stem the tide. But the obvious teamwork, and the splendid
feats of the 'Varsity's close defense, could not be equaled. The
work of Stuart, Brooks and Leibensperger was especially commendable in this department, the
beautiful stops of Stuart at goal
bringing forth many a cheer from
the grandstand.
The game was called shortly
after 4 o'clock, and after the ball
had see-sawed up and down the
field, Hopkins scored the first tally
after three minutes of play. The
goal was a peculiar one, the ball
suddenly rolling from a melee before the midshipmen's goal and just
crossing the line as Manley, the
Navy goal-keeper. dragged it away
with his stick. Chandler scored for
Navy two minutes later by a pretty
shot past Stuart. Hopkins now
endeavored to break down the successful dodging of the midshipmen.
Shortly after this, Nelson, on a
sprint from the center of the field,
sent the ball to Voshell, who scored
past Goal-keeper Manley. By this
time Hopkins had Navy on the
jump.
Troxell was sent in to relieve
Prince. He almost immediately
received the ball on a pass, ran to
the crease and scored Hopkins'
third goal. The 'Varsity easily outplayed the midshipmen in this half,
which ended with the score 3 to I
in their favor.
In the second period the battle
was more of a nip-and-tuck affair,
each side managing to net one goal.
Navy scored first, the ball going
past Huck and high over Stuart's
shoulder. Soon after this Troxell
scored for Hopkins.
The lineup:
Navy.
Hopkins.
Position.

Although Tappan proved the star
of the meet, scoring nineteen points,
and Captain Connolly scored eight
more for the Black and Blue, the
Navy track and field men gained a
decisive victory over the crippled
Hopkins team in the annual dual
contest at Annapolis last Saturday
by the score of 58 to 30.* The first
relay team were the only scorers for
Hopkins besides these two stars.
Two teams from each side enter,ed
this one-Mile relay event, and the
first Hopkins four, consisting of
Uhler, Straus, Binford and F. P.
Hall, all of whom had already taken
part in other events, scored second
in the event, giving Hopkins three
points to five.
Hopkins entered the contest with
a team very much crippled. The
recent examinations were responsible
for several losses, and two. or three
of the most reliable men were not in
good condition. Wright, the most
promising sprinter on the squad,
was suffering from a pulled muscle,
and did not make the trip; while
Uhler and Binford were below their
usual marks.
Ben Tappan piled up his nineteen points by winning both the
high and low hurdle races and the
high jump, and scoring second in
the broad jump and tying with two
Navy men for second in the pole
vault. Connolly took first in the
board jump and second in the high
jump. A very close finish occurred
in the 440-yard run. The three
Navy men and F. P. Hall, of Hopkins, were closely bunched together
for the last thirty yards, but Hall
was only able to get third place.

When Greek Meets Greek.

Seldom do lovers of tennis have
• the opportunity of seeing a rousing
match between two experts who
pursue precisely the same tactics.
On Friday afternoon at 2.30 o'clock
the Princeton tenhis team will meet
the 'Varsity" on the Homewood
courts. Old Nassau is led by
George M. Church, who is seventh
in the National ranking; who holds
the intercollegiate championship by
virtue of his victory last fall over
.Norris Williams; who has the cup
for the Delaware State championship in his possession, etc., etc.
American Lawn Tennis says of
Church: "He is a decidedly unorthodox, and therefore interesting,
player. He is essentially a net player, and an exceptionally good one,
too. He subordinates everything
else to his desire to reach the net.
And he manages to get there usually. He invariably follows in his
service, which is fast and well
placed, with a little twist, and
which, backed up with his fine volleying, is very hard to break
through. On his opponent's delivery he utilizes all conceivable opportunities to come up, and, indeed,
some that others might think inconceivable. His overhead work is
the best part of his game. He
smashes lobs as effectively as anybody in the world. He does not hit

HISTORY TEACHERS MEET HERE
Association of History Teachers Hold
Convention in McCoy Hall Pres.
Goodnow Welcomes Educators.

The thirteenth annual spring
meeting of the Association of History Teachers was held on Friday
and Saturday of last week in McCoy Hall. Fifty prominent educators from institutions of learning
in the East were welcomed at the
opening of the first session in the
Donovan Room by President Good
now, who was introduced by Prof.
Henry Johnson, of Columbia University, and president of the Teachers' Association.
Dr. Goodnow told the visiting
delegates that he was glad to have
them gather here, since Johns Hopkins has always been interested in
the teaching of history and since he
himself began his career as a teacher
of history some thirty years ago.
At the conclusion of Dr. Goodnow's
remarks, papers were read showing
the changes which have been made
in the method of teaching history
in many of the leading institutions
of the.East. It was pointed out that
there was a tendency to compare
past events with incidents of today
in an effort to establish the relationship between them.
Papers were read by Dr. Thomas
H. Briggs, of Columbia, and Prof.
R. W. Kelsey, of Haverford University, as well as by several other
history teachers of prominence from
institutions in the East. In the
evening a dinner was given the
delegates in the Donovan Room, at
which an address was made by Dr.
J. M. Vincent of this University.
On Saturday morning several
topics were brought up for open
discussion at the meeting. PrOf.
Charles W. Spencer, of Princeton,
Prof. Philip Dougherty, of the
Polytechnic Institute of Baltimore,
and Miss Louise J. Hedge, of the
Brooklyn Training School, discussed
various phases of educational work.
One of the topics brought up was
the "Differentiation of History in
the High School from History in
the High School."

Half 1915 Hullabaloo in Printers' Hands.

More than half of the Hullabaloo
has been in the hands of the printers
for the past week or so, and the
Board expects to start the proofreading as soon as the printers
complete their work. To allow several delinquent advertisers to get
their ads, in the book, the business
department has decided to withhold
one section for a few days longer.
All of the art work has either been
handed in or is expected to come
in during the next few days.
The Hullabaloo will contain many
cuts of the new buildings at Homewood and also many cartoons characteristic of class-room occurrences.
The section entitled 'Statistics" will
contain much interesting information. Another new feature of the
book will be the distribution of college views throughout the advertising section.

Art Editors of 1916"Hullabaloo"Elected.

A meeting of the Board of Editors of the 1916 Hullabaloo, the primary purpose of which was to elect
art editors, was held recently at
Editor - in - Chief Tingley's home.
The announcement of the Board
some time ago that all candidates
for the positions should submit
specimens of their work and that
from the merits of these the editors
would be elected_ brought forth unusual interest among the artists of
the class, with the result that a large
number of sketches were submitted.
The competition was close. Walter
A. Wood, Jr., was elected art editor
and Frederick K. Bell was selected
as his assistant. Following this
election the Board formulated its
plans in brief concerning the different branches of publishing the class
book.

Polly Polarbear, the trained Russian (lancer, has lost her suit against
the Cohen-Cohn Company for unexpired contract. This loss, however, will hardly prevent Miss
Polarbear from continuing her
dance.
It is rumored that Sweety Darling, last season's hit in the "Yellow
Piano," is dissatisfied with her husband, Tim Fogarty, and is trying to
have him sent on the road.
Lulu Skittle, formerly with Pete
Sullivan in the "Pipping Washboard" has settled down with her
mother in a flat on 136th street.
Miss Skittle declares positively that
she will never dance again on account of the sad loss of her right
leg.
Saddie and Sammie in their clever
skit "Four Large Feet of Comedy,"
are now touring the Middle West in
their private freight car, expecting
to return East in time to die.

Victrola victim, has signed a twoyear contract with vaudeville. Mr.

Wilson Barrett used to tell an
amusing story against himself. At
a time when he had a lot of workmen redecorating his private residence, thinking to give them a treat,
he asked if, after work one evening,
they would like to have seats to go
and see him play in "The Lights o'
London" at the Princess Theatre.
They said they didn't mind if they
did, and being complimentary tickets, all went on a Saturday night to
see their employer's performance.
At the end of the week Barrett's
eye caught sight of this item against

sheet: "Saturday night—Four hours
overtime at Princess Theatre, eight
shillings."—Yid-Bits.

Every student of the University is a

This is the first real "party" that

in many years. It is given primarily to receive our new coach,
and for the Hopkins students. But
it is also aimed to give the boys who
will be entering college in the next
year or two a glimpse of real Hopkins spirit and loyalty. Under these
conditions, surely no man need be
asked further to come.

In the niost clean-cut and interesting exhibition of baseball that has
been seen at Homewood this year,
Hopkins defeated Washington College Saturday by the score of 2 to I.
The game was a true pitchers' duel,
each team getting only four hits; and
the 'Varsity was able to win only by
taking advantage of Bourland's
error in the eighth and by holding
the enemy to their lone tally by
some of the cleverest fielding seen
this year. at Homewood.
The team has shown a remarkable
improvement in fielding. Worthington had four outs and five assists
to his credit without an error. He
handled himself in excellent form
and scooped up everything that
came his way in faultless manner.
On two occasions he ran out into
center field and made sensational
catches of high flies. Phythyon,
playing in the outfield in "Babe"
Ewing's absence, made a beautiful
catch of Bourland's long fly in the
seventh.
One of the most pleasing features
of the game was the fielding of
Howell at first. When it was first
announced that Butler would not be
able to play, a serious problem confronted the coach, but Howell's playing on Saturday showed Hopkins
that they have a man who is able to
meet the emergency. Howell accepted fifteen chances without an indication of a fumble. Howell also
figured in two double plays, both of
which were largely instrumental in
keeping the score of Washington
College to one tally. •
More encouraging, however, than
the playing of individuals was the
machine-like precision that accompanied the playing of the whole
team. Coach Hooper :has trained
his men well. The score:
.7Qhns Hopkins.

The last four of the Turnbull
lectures were delivered by Sir Walter Raleigh, of Oxford University,
on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday
and Thursday afternoons of last
week. The lectures, which dealt
with "The Reviewers,- ."Hazlitt,"
"Lamb" and "Landor,- respectively,
were easily the most interesting of
the course, partly because the subjects made it possible for Sir Walter to express his own views and
impressions, and partly because he
seemed to take an even keener delight in delivering them than in discussing the topics chosen for the
first two talks.
The lecture on "The Reviewers"
was by far the most original and
witty of the six discussions. After
dealing briefly with the futility of a
large body of criticism, Sir Walter
selected .the critics of the early nineteenth century, and devoted his consideration exclusively to them and
to their work. His discourse
abounded in clever epigrams and
ant phrases that embellished the
scholarly manner in which the subject was treated.
The following lecture, which dealt
with Hazlitt, proved of almost equal
interest. The life, the personality
and the work of the delightful essayist were carefully considered, and
the memory of a man who has been
all too effectually forgotten and become but a name even to many comparatively well read and thoroughly
educated people, was made fresh in
the minds of the audience. Details
of the personal habits of Hazlitt
were received with particular interest, for his character was in many
ways a most amazing one.
On Wednesday the speaker dealt
with Charles Lamb, shyest and most
retiring of men, after first apologizing for dragging so thorough a
recluse from his beloved retirement
into the light of common day. The
life of the writer was first discussed,
following which his work, which
was written late, and has aptly been
called a happy accident, received attention. The lecture was divided
into three sub-heads, which concerned themselves with the sayings,
essays and letters of Lamb. Some
of the wittiest remarks of the famous punster were quoted, and several of his letters, among them one
to Mrs. Wordsworth, were read.
The last lecture took for its subject Walter Savage Landor, a writer
who, said Sir Walter, is liked by
many, but enthusiastically loved and
extensively read by but very few.
The fact that in Landor the man

The representatives of the Grotius Society of Johns Hopkins University were awarded the unanimous
decision of the board of judges
in a debate held with the team
of the Zelosophic Society of the
University of Pennsylvania at 8.30
last Friday night in the University
chapel. The debate was the fourth
that has been held between the two
societies, and the first that has been
won by a Grotius team.
Dr. John C. French, who was the
presiding officer of the evening, first
apologized for the small number
who had been able to be present,
adding that the debaters, like John
Milton, were assured of "fit audideuce, though few." He then introduced Mr. Edmund M. Spieker,
who rendered a piano selection with
characteristic ability and power.
The Grotius speakers defended
the affirmative of the subject: "Resolved, that a policy of colonial expansion is desirable for the modern
State." Their team was composed
of Cecil H. Bagley, '17; Reuben
Oppenheimer, 'i8; and Avra M.
Warren, '15 (chairman), while the
Pennsylvania debaters were D. T.
Balmer, '16; A. L. Horst, '16; and
H. H. Burton (captain).
Mr. Bagley opened the debate for
the affirmative with a well-ordered
and convincing speech that cleared
the field for his team-mates. Mr.
Oppenheimer, the second Grotius
speaker, was emphatic and his
speech was most capable, while
Avra M. Warren summed up the
position of the affirmative in a witty, extemporaneous address, which
was effective and to the point. All
three.speakers did! well in rebuttal,
but to Mr. Warren must be given
chief laurels, as he seemed to possess the most thorough acquaintance with his subject and was most
successful in riddling the contentions of the opposition.
Balmer, who opened the question
for the negative, dealt with the history of colonial expansion. His
speech was good from the standpoint of argument, but lost somewhat in the delivery. Horst was
the most easy and fluent talker on
the Zelosophic team, both in his
first address and his rebuttal. Burton, who spoke last, emphasized the
lack of land! open to colonization.
After a short interval, Prof. Wilbur F. Smith, chairman of the
judges, announced the decision of
his colleagues, Rev. Robert P. Kerr,
D. D., and Summerfield Baldwin.
The decision, which had been
reached without consultation, was
unanimously in favor of the Hopkins men.

Work has been started on the
new Yale boathouse at Gales Ferry.
The building will be 42 feet wide
and 85 feet in length and will be
supported on piles; a platform will
be constructed at one end with large
aprons and a 6o-foot float extending out over the water. The boatroom takes up most of the first floor.
On the same floor will be the dressing and shower rooms for the use
of the crew. Servants will have
separate accommodations on the second floor. A stairway in the entrance hall leads to the second story,
where there will be sixteen separate
bedrooms and a sitting-room open-

ing on a balcony which overlooks
the water. The new boathouse will
be a great improvement upon the
old one, which has stood for twentyfive years and has long been inadequate.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 19, 1915.
HOPKINS DEFEATS MIDSHIPMEN

TAPPAN STARS IN NAVY MEET

Black and Blue Lacrosse Team Scores
First Victory Over Navy in Three
Years—Middies Outplayed.

"Old Reliable" Makes Nineteen Points of
'Varsity's Total of Thirty Navy
Rolls Up Fifty-Eight Points.

For the first time in three years
the 'Varsity twelve triumphed over
Navy in the annual lacrosse battle
at Annapolis, the score being 4 to 2.
A large number of rooters accompanied the team and added to the
enthusiasm throughout the contest.
It was a clear-cut and decisive
victory, Hopkins outplaying the
Annapolis team from start to finish.
However, the game.was desperately
fought, the sailor lads trying their
best to stem the tide. But the obvious teamwork, and the splendid
feats of the 'Varsity's close defense, could not be equaled. The
work of Stuart, Brooks and Leibensperger was especially commendable in this department, the
beautiful stops of Stuart at goal
bringing forth many a cheer from
the grandstand.
The game was called shortly
after 4 o'clock, and after the ball
had see-sawed up and down the
field, Hopkins scored the first tally
after three minutes of play. The
goal was a peculiar one, the ball
suddenly rolling from a melee before the midshipmen's goal and just
crossing the line as Manley, the
Navy goal-keeper. dragged it away
with his stick. Chandler scored for
Navy two minutes later by a pretty
shot past Stuart. Hopkins now
endeavored to break down the successful dodging of the midshipmen.
Shortly after this, Nelson, on a
sprint from the center of the field,
sent the ball to Voshell, who scored
past Goal-keeper Manley. By this
time Hopkins had Navy on the
jump.
Troxell was sent in to relieve
Prince. He almost immediately
received the ball on a pass, ran to
the crease and scored Hopkins'
third goal. The 'Varsity easily outplayed the midshipmen in this half,
which ended with the score 3 to I
in their favor.
In the second period the battle
was more of a nip-and-tuck affair,
each side managing to net one goal.
Navy scored first, the ball going
past Huck and high over Stuart's
shoulder. Soon after this Troxell
scored for Hopkins.
The lineup:
Navy.
Hopkins.
Position.

Although Tappan proved the star
of the meet, scoring nineteen points,
and Captain Connolly scored eight
more for the Black and Blue, the
Navy track and field men gained a
decisive victory over the crippled
Hopkins team in the annual dual
contest at Annapolis last Saturday
by the score of 58 to 30.* The first
relay team were the only scorers for
Hopkins besides these two stars.
Two teams from each side enter,ed
this one-Mile relay event, and the
first Hopkins four, consisting of
Uhler, Straus, Binford and F. P.
Hall, all of whom had already taken
part in other events, scored second
in the event, giving Hopkins three
points to five.
Hopkins entered the contest with
a team very much crippled. The
recent examinations were responsible
for several losses, and two. or three
of the most reliable men were not in
good condition. Wright, the most
promising sprinter on the squad,
was suffering from a pulled muscle,
and did not make the trip; while
Uhler and Binford were below their
usual marks.
Ben Tappan piled up his nineteen points by winning both the
high and low hurdle races and the
high jump, and scoring second in
the broad jump and tying with two
Navy men for second in the pole
vault. Connolly took first in the
board jump and second in the high
jump. A very close finish occurred
in the 440-yard run. The three
Navy men and F. P. Hall, of Hopkins, were closely bunched together
for the last thirty yards, but Hall
was only able to get third place.

When Greek Meets Greek.

Seldom do lovers of tennis have
• the opportunity of seeing a rousing
match between two experts who
pursue precisely the same tactics.
On Friday afternoon at 2.30 o'clock
the Princeton tenhis team will meet
the 'Varsity" on the Homewood
courts. Old Nassau is led by
George M. Church, who is seventh
in the National ranking; who holds
the intercollegiate championship by
virtue of his victory last fall over
.Norris Williams; who has the cup
for the Delaware State championship in his possession, etc., etc.
American Lawn Tennis says of
Church: "He is a decidedly unorthodox, and therefore interesting,
player. He is essentially a net player, and an exceptionally good one,
too. He subordinates everything
else to his desire to reach the net.
And he manages to get there usually. He invariably follows in his
service, which is fast and well
placed, with a little twist, and
which, backed up with his fine volleying, is very hard to break
through. On his opponent's delivery he utilizes all conceivable opportunities to come up, and, indeed,
some that others might think inconceivable. His overhead work is
the best part of his game. He
smashes lobs as effectively as anybody in the world. He does not hit

HISTORY TEACHERS MEET HERE
Association of History Teachers Hold
Convention in McCoy Hall Pres.
Goodnow Welcomes Educators.

The thirteenth annual spring
meeting of the Association of History Teachers was held on Friday
and Saturday of last week in McCoy Hall. Fifty prominent educators from institutions of learning
in the East were welcomed at the
opening of the first session in the
Donovan Room by President Good
now, who was introduced by Prof.
Henry Johnson, of Columbia University, and president of the Teachers' Association.
Dr. Goodnow told the visiting
delegates that he was glad to have
them gather here, since Johns Hopkins has always been interested in
the teaching of history and since he
himself began his career as a teacher
of history some thirty years ago.
At the conclusion of Dr. Goodnow's
remarks, papers were read showing
the changes which have been made
in the method of teaching history
in many of the leading institutions
of the.East. It was pointed out that
there was a tendency to compare
past events with incidents of today
in an effort to establish the relationship between them.
Papers were read by Dr. Thomas
H. Briggs, of Columbia, and Prof.
R. W. Kelsey, of Haverford University, as well as by several other
history teachers of prominence from
institutions in the East. In the
evening a dinner was given the
delegates in the Donovan Room, at
which an address was made by Dr.
J. M. Vincent of this University.
On Saturday morning several
topics were brought up for open
discussion at the meeting. PrOf.
Charles W. Spencer, of Princeton,
Prof. Philip Dougherty, of the
Polytechnic Institute of Baltimore,
and Miss Louise J. Hedge, of the
Brooklyn Training School, discussed
various phases of educational work.
One of the topics brought up was
the "Differentiation of History in
the High School from History in
the High School."

Half 1915 Hullabaloo in Printers' Hands.

More than half of the Hullabaloo
has been in the hands of the printers
for the past week or so, and the
Board expects to start the proofreading as soon as the printers
complete their work. To allow several delinquent advertisers to get
their ads, in the book, the business
department has decided to withhold
one section for a few days longer.
All of the art work has either been
handed in or is expected to come
in during the next few days.
The Hullabaloo will contain many
cuts of the new buildings at Homewood and also many cartoons characteristic of class-room occurrences.
The section entitled 'Statistics" will
contain much interesting information. Another new feature of the
book will be the distribution of college views throughout the advertising section.

Art Editors of 1916"Hullabaloo"Elected.

A meeting of the Board of Editors of the 1916 Hullabaloo, the primary purpose of which was to elect
art editors, was held recently at
Editor - in - Chief Tingley's home.
The announcement of the Board
some time ago that all candidates
for the positions should submit
specimens of their work and that
from the merits of these the editors
would be elected_ brought forth unusual interest among the artists of
the class, with the result that a large
number of sketches were submitted.
The competition was close. Walter
A. Wood, Jr., was elected art editor
and Frederick K. Bell was selected
as his assistant. Following this
election the Board formulated its
plans in brief concerning the different branches of publishing the class
book.

Polly Polarbear, the trained Russian (lancer, has lost her suit against
the Cohen-Cohn Company for unexpired contract. This loss, however, will hardly prevent Miss
Polarbear from continuing her
dance.
It is rumored that Sweety Darling, last season's hit in the "Yellow
Piano," is dissatisfied with her husband, Tim Fogarty, and is trying to
have him sent on the road.
Lulu Skittle, formerly with Pete
Sullivan in the "Pipping Washboard" has settled down with her

Wilson Barrett used to tell an
amusing story against himself. At
a time when he had a lot of workmen redecorating his private residence, thinking to give them a treat,
he asked if, after work one evening,
they would like to have seats to go
and see him play in "The Lights o'
London" at the Princess Theatre.
They said they didn't mind if they
did, and being complimentary tickets, all went on a Saturday night to
see their employer's performance.
At the end of the week Barrett's
eye caught sight of this item against
each workman's name on the pay
sheet: "Saturday night—Four hours
overtime at Princess Theatre, eight
shillings."—Yid-Bits.

SIR WALTER CONCLUDES SERIES

this will in no way affect the Hopkins students.
The prep school boys will be the
visitors of the Athletic Association.
Every student of the University is a
member of the Athletic Association,
and therefore a host of the visitors.
And accordingly, in addition to
helping make the evening one of the
most enjoyable and inspiring that
has ever been arranged, every man
must pull his utmost to have Hopkins out in full force to welcome all
of the youngsters who will feed the
University in the future; to welcome the new coach in a manner
that is worthy of Hopkins, and to
give Brickley a chance to feel that
Hopkins men are all "right back
of him all the way through."
This is the first real "party" that
the Athletic Association has given
in many years. It is given primarily to receive our new coach,
and for the Hopkins students. But
it is also aimed to give the boys who
will be entering college in the next
year or two a glimpse of real Hopkins spirit and loyalty. Under these
conditions, surely no man need be
asked further to come.
The coaches of all the teams have
relaxed training rules for the evening, and all members of the spring
teams will be allowed to attend and
remain throughout the celebrations,
which will probably be over by io
o'clock.

and the work are• separate and distinct was first remarked by the lecturer, and the characteristic quietness and composure of his poetry
and prose were then commented
upon. The shorter poems, particularly the quatrains and certain
passages in the longer poems,
were considered by the speaker to
be the best of Landor's work, although the. "Imaginary Conversations" and the critical articles were
found to be distinctly worthy of consideration. Such biographical matters as account of Ihe poet's marriage, or of the throwing of a cook
from the window, proved highly
amusing, and illustrated the fact
that even when Landor was a very
old man he preserved almost too
much of the impetuosity and
thoughtlessness that are customarily
attributed to youth.
At the close of the last lecture,
and on the motion of Dr. Bright, of
the graduate English department, a
vote of thanks was tendered for the
generous provision that made possible the Turnbull lectures, and also
to Sir Walter Raleigh for delivering the course in 1915. The lecturer replied , by expressing, in a
short speech, his gratitude for the
kindness and consideration manifested towards him.
